documentation.short: Sensing demo application.
documentation.long:
Sensing demo application. See README.txt file in this directory for usage instructions and have a look at tinyos-2.x/doc/html/tutorial/lesson5.html for a general tutorial on sensing in TinyOS.
@author Jan Hauer

Measure cpu clock frequency at boot time.
documentation.long:
Measure cpu clock frequency at boot time. Provides an Atm128Calibrate interface so that other components can adjust their calibration as needed.
@author David Gay

documentation.short: RealMain implements the TinyOS boot sequence, as documented in TEP 107.
The TinyOS scheduler.
Implementation of TEP 112 (Microcontroller Power Management) for the Atmega128.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.
Components should never wire to this component.
Millisecond timer for the mica family (see TEP102).
Configure hardware timer 0 for use as the mica family's millisecond timer.
documentation.long:
Configure hardware timer 0 for use as the mica family's millisecond timer. This component does not follow the TEP102 HAL guidelines as there is only one compare register for timer 0, which is used to implement HilTimerMilliC. Hence it isn't useful to expose an AlarmMilliC or CounterMillIC component.
@author David Gay <dgay@intel-research.net> @author Martin Turon <mturon@xbow.com>

documentation.short: Build a 32-bit alarm and counter from the atmega128's 8-bit timer 0 in asynchronous mode.
Build a 32-bit alarm and counter from the atmega128's 8-bit timer 0 in asynchronous mode.
Simple wrapper around the actual timer implementation that automatically wires it to McuSleepC for low-power calculations..
HPL interface to Atmega128 timer 0 in ASYNC mode.
AlarmToTimerC converts a 32-bit Alarm to a Timer.
VirtualizeTimerC uses a single Timer to create up to 255 virtual timers.
CounterToLocalTimeC converts a 32-bit LocalTime to a Counter.
The micaZ doesn't have any built-in sensors - the DemoSensor returns a constant value of 0xbeef, or just reads the ground value for the stream sensor.
Battery Voltage.
documentation.long:
Battery Voltage. The returned value represents the difference between the battery voltage and V_BG (1.23V). The formula to convert it to mV is: 1223 * 1024 / value.
@author Razvan Musaloiu-E.

documentation.short: Provide, as per TEP101, arbitrated access via a Read interface to the Atmega128 ADC.
documentation.long:
Provide, as per TEP101, arbitrated access via a Read interface to the Atmega128 ADC. Users of this component must link it to an implementation of Atm128AdcConfig which provides the ADC parameters (channel, etc).
@author David Gay

documentation.short: Support component for AdcReadClientC and AdcReadNowClientC.
documentation.long:
Support component for AdcReadClientC and AdcReadNowClientC.
@author David Gay

documentation.short: HAL for the Atmega128 A/D conversion susbsystem.
Internal component of the Atmega128 A/D HAL.
HPL for the Atmega128 A/D conversion susbsystem.
HPL for the Atmega128 A/D conversion susbsystem.

Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceDefaultOwner interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceDefaultOwner interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108. It provides arbitration to a shared resource in a Round Robin fashion. An array is used to keep track of which users have put in requests for the resource. Upon the release of the resource by one of these users, the array is checked and the next user (in Round Robin order) that has a pending request will ge granted control of the resource. If there are no pending requests, then the resource is granted to the default user. If a new request is made, the default user will release the resource, and it will be granted to the requesting cleint. @param resourceName -- The name of the Resource being shared @author Kevin Klues (klues@tkn.tu-berlin.de)

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ResourceRequested, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceDefaultOwner interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ResourceRequested, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceDefaultOwner interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108. It provides arbitration to a shared resource. A Queue is used to keep track of which users have put in requests for the resource. Upon the release of the resource by one of these users, the queue is checked and the next user that has a pending request will ge granted control of the resource. If there are no pending requests, then the user of the ResourceDefaultOwner interface gains access to the resource, and holds onto it until another user makes a request. @param default_owner_id -- The id of the default owner of this resource @author Kevin Klues (klues@tkn.tu-berlin.de) @author Philip Levis

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This is the internal implementation of the standard power management policy for managing the power states of non-virtualized devices.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This is the internal implementation of the standard power management policy for managing the power states of non-virtualized devices. Non-virtualized devices are shared using a parameterized Resource interface, and are powered down according to some policy whenever there are no more pending requests to that Resource. The policy implemented by this component is to power down a device as soon as it becomes free. Such a policy is useful whenever a device has a negligible wake-up latency. There is no cost associated with waiting for the device to power up, so it can be powered on and off as often as possible.

Powerdown of the device is done through the AsyncStdControl interface, so this component can only be used with those devices that provide that interface.

For devices providing either the StdControl or SplitControl interfaces, please use either the StdControlPowerManagerC component or the SplitControlPowerManagerC component respectively. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This is the internal implementation of the standard power management policy for managing the power states of non-virtualized devices.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This is the internal implementation of the standard power management policy for managing the power states of non-virtualized devices. Non-virtualized devices are shared using a parameterized Resource interface, and are powered down according to some policy whenever there are no more pending requests to that Resource. The policy implemented by this component is to power down a device as soon as it becomes free. Such a policy is useful whenever a device has a negligible wake-up latency. There is no cost associated with waiting for the device to power up, so it can be powered on and off as often as possible. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

This is the internal implementation of the standard power management policy for managing the power states of non-virtualized devices. Non-virtualized devices are shared using a parameterized Resource interface, and are powered down according to some policy whenever there are no more pending requests to that Resource. The policy implemented by this component is to power down a device as soon as it becomes free. Such a policy is useful whenever a device has a negligible wake-up latency. There is no cost associated with waiting for the device to power up, so it can be powered on and off as often as possible.

Powerdown of the device is done through the AsyncStdControl interface, so this component can only be used with those devices that provide that interface.

For devices providing either the StdControl or SplitControl interfaces, please use either the StdControlPowerManagerC component or the SplitControlPowerManagerC component respectively. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Implement arbitrated access to a Read interface, based on an underlying arbitrated Resource interface.
Interface that notifies components when TinyOS has booted (initialized all of its components), as discussed in TEP 107.
Signaled when the system has booted successfully.
The Read interface is intended for split-phase low-rate or high-latency reading of small values.
Initiates a read of the value.
documentation.long:
Initiates a read of the value.
@return SUCCESS if a readDone() event will eventually come back.

documentation.short: Signals the completion of the read().
A Timer is TinyOS's general purpose timing interface.
documentation.long:
A Timer is TinyOS's general purpose timing interface. For more precise timing, you may wish to use a (platform-specific) component offering an Alarm interface.

A Timer is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Alarm. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return the current time.
documentation.long: Return the current time. @return Current time.

documentation.short: Signaled when the timer expires (one-shot) or repeats (periodic).
documentation.long: Signaled when the timer expires (one-shot) or repeats (periodic).

documentation.short: Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units.
documentation.long:
Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units. Replaces any current timer settings. The fired will be signaled every dt units (first event at t0+dt units). Periodic timers set in the past will get a bunch of events in succession, until the timer "catches up".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for timer. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Check if this is a one-shot timer.
documentation.long: Check if this is a one-shot timer. @return TRUE for one-shot timers, FALSE for periodic timers.

documentation.short: Return the delay or period for the previously started timer.
Return the time anchor for the previously started timer or the time of the previous event for periodic timers.
documentation.long: Return the time anchor for the previously started timer or the time of the previous event for periodic timers. The next fired event will occur at gett0() + getdt(). @return Timer's base time.

documentation.short: Check if timer is running.
Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units.
documentation.long: Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units. Replaces any current timer settings. Equivalent to startPeriodicAt(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled every dt units (first event in dt units). @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short timer to time t0+dt.
documentation.long:
Set a single-short timer to time t0+dt. Replaces any current timer settings. The fired will be signaled when the timer expires. Timers set in the past will fire "soon".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for timer. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short timer to some time units in the future.
documentation.long: Set a single-short timer to some time units in the future. Replaces any current timer settings. Equivalent to startOneShotAt(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled when the timer expires. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Cancel a timer.
documentation.long: Cancel a timer.

documentation.short: Initialize this component.
This interface provides functions to compute ATmega128 configuration values that are clock-rate dependent.
documentation.long:
This interface provides functions to compute ATmega128 configuration values that are clock-rate dependent. These include:
  • the ADC prescaler value necessary for full precision
  • values for the UBRR registers to achieve a specific baud rate
  • any adjustment necessary to values passed to some platform-provided AlarmMicroXXC components to get more accurate timing
  • the number of cycles per 1/32768s (a typical implementation of this interface will measure this value at boot time and use it to compute the values above)
@author David Gay

documentation.short: Return the value to use for the baudrate register to achieve a particular baud rate.
documentation.long: Return the value to use for the baudrate register to achieve a particular baud rate. Assumes U2X=1 (the USART is being run at double speed).

documentation.short: Return CPU cycles per 1/32768s.
documentation.long: Return CPU cycles per 1/32768s. @return CPU cycles.

documentation.short: Convert n microseconds into a value suitable for use with AlarmMicro32C Alarms.
Convert values used by AlarmMicro32C Alarms into actual microseconds.
Return the smallest ADC prescaler value which guaranteers full ADC precision.

documentation.long: @author Joe Polastre

documentation.short: The interface to a TinyOS task scheduler.
Initialize the scheduler.
documentation.long: Initialize the scheduler.

documentation.short: Enter an infinite task-running loop.
documentation.long: Enter an infinite task-running loop. Put the MCU into a low power state when the processor is idle (task queue empty, waiting for interrupts). This call never returns.

documentation.short: Run the next task if one is waiting, otherwise return immediately.
Post this task to the TinyOS scheduler.
documentation.long:
Post this task to the TinyOS scheduler. At some later time, depending on the scheduling policy, the scheduler will signal the <tt>run()</tt> event.
@return SUCCESS if task was successfuly posted; the semantics of a non-SUCCESS return value depend on the implementation of this interface (the class of task).

documentation.short: Event from the scheduler to run this task.
documentation.long: Event from the scheduler to run this task. Following the TinyOS concurrency model, the codes invoked from <tt>run()</tt> signals execute atomically with respect to one another, but can be preempted by async commands/events.

documentation.short: Interface to instruct the MCU to enter a low power state.
Called by the scheduler to put the MCU to sleep.
documentation.long: Called by the scheduler to put the MCU to sleep. *

documentation.short: Called when computing the low power state, in order to allow a high-level component to institute a lower bound.
documentation.long:
Called when computing the low power state, in order to allow a high-level component to institute a lower bound. Because this command originates deep within the basic TinyOS scheduling mechanisms, it should be used very sparingly. Refer to TEP 112 for details.
@return the lowest power state the system can enter to meet the requirements of this component

documentation.short: Interface to instruct TinyOS that the low-power state of the MCU may have changed.
Called by any component to tell TinyOS that the MCU low power state may have changed.
documentation.long: Called by any component to tell TinyOS that the MCU low power state may have changed. Generally, this should be called whenever a peripheral/timer is started/stopped.

documentation.short: A LocalTime interface counts time in some units.
documentation.long:
A LocalTime interface counts time in some units. If you need to detect time overflow, you should use a component offering the Counter interface.

The LocalTime interface is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Counter. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return current time.
A Counter counts time in some units and in some width, signaling overflow.
documentation.long:
A Counter counts time in some units and in some width, signaling overflow.

A Counter is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

A Counter's second parameter is its "width", i.e., the number of bits used to represent time values. Width is indicated by including the appropriate size integer type as a Counter parameter.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Counter. @param size_type An integer type representing time values for this Counter. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return counter value.
Cancel a pending overflow interrupt.
Return TRUE if an overflow event will occur after the outermost atomic block is exits.
Signals that the current time has overflowed.
documentation.long: Signals that the current time has overflowed. That is, the current time has wrapped around from its maximum value to zero.

documentation.short: An Alarm is a low-level interface intended for precise timing.
documentation.long:
An Alarm is a low-level interface intended for precise timing.

An Alarm is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

An Alarm's second parameter is its "width", i.e., the number of bits used to represent time values. Width is indicated by including the appropriate size integer type as an Alarm parameter.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Alarm. @param size_type An integer type representing time values for this Alarm. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return the current time.
documentation.long: Return the current time. @return Current time.

documentation.short: Signaled when the alarm expires.
documentation.long: Signaled when the alarm expires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short alarm to time t0+dt.
documentation.long:
Set a single-short alarm to time t0+dt. Replaces any current alarm time. The fired will be signaled when the alarm expires. Alarms set in the past will fire "soon".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for alarm. @param dt Alarm time as offset from t0.

documentation.short: Check if alarm is running.
documentation.long: Check if alarm is running. Note that a FALSE return does not indicate that the fired event will not be signaled (it may have already started executing, but not reached your code yet). @return TRUE if the alarm is still running.

documentation.short: Return the time the currently running alarm will fire or the time that the previously running alarm was set to fire.
Set a single-short alarm to some time units in the future.
documentation.long: Set a single-short alarm to some time units in the future. Replaces any current alarm time. Equivalent to start(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled when the alarm expires. @param dt Time until the alarm fires.

documentation.short: Cancel an alarm.
documentation.long: Cancel an alarm. Note that the fired event may have already been signaled (even if your code has not yet started executing).

documentation.short: HPL Interface to Atmega128 8-bit timer control registers
documentation.long:
HPL Interface to Atmega128 8-bit timer control registers
@author Martin Turon <mturon@xbow.com>

documentation.short: Timer control register: Direct access

documentation.long: Check if compare register OCR0 is busy (should not be updated if true) @return TRUE if OCR0 is busy, FALSE otherwise (can be updated)

Check if current timer value (TCNT0) is busy (should not be updated if true)
documentation.long: Check if current timer value (TCNT0) is busy (should not be updated if true) @return TRUE if TCNT0 is busy, FALSE otherwise (can be updated)

documentation.long: Read timer0 asynchronous status register (ASSR) @return Current value of ASSR

documentation.short: Set timer0 asynchronous status register (ASSR)
documentation.long: Set timer0 asynchronous status register (ASSR) @param x New value for ASSR

documentation.short: HPL Interface to Atmega128 compare registers.
Did compare interrupt occur?
documentation.long: Did compare interrupt occur? @return TRUE if compare triggered, FALSE otherwise

documentation.short: Signalled on interrupt.
documentation.long: Signalled on interrupt. *

documentation.short: Get the compare time to fire on.
documentation.long: Get the compare time to fire on. @return the compare time value

documentation.short: Clear the compare interrupt flag.
documentation.long: Clear the compare interrupt flag. *

documentation.short: Is compare interrupt on?
documentation.long: Is compare interrupt on? @return TRUE if compare enabled, FALSE otherwise

documentation.short: Set the compare time to fire on.
documentation.long: Set the compare time to fire on. @param t the compare time to set

documentation.short: Enable the compare interrupt.
documentation.long: Enable the compare interrupt. *

documentation.short: Turn off comparee interrupts.
documentation.long: Turn off comparee interrupts. *

documentation.short: Basic interface to the hardware timers on an ATmega128.
documentation.long:
Basic interface to the hardware timers on an ATmega128.

This interface is designed to be independent of whether the underlying hardware is an 8-bit or 16-bit wide counter. As such, timer_size is specified via a generics parameter. Because this is exposing a common subset of functionality that all ATmega128 hardware timers share, all that is exposed is access to the overflow capability. Compare and capture functionality are exposed on separate interfaces to allow easy configurability via wiring.

This interface provides four major groups of functionality:

  1. Timer Value: get/set current time
  2. Overflow Interrupt event
  3. Control of Overflow Interrupt: start/stop/clear...
  4. Timer Initialization: turn on/off clock source
@author Martin Turon

documentation.short: Turn off the clock.
documentation.long: Turn off the clock. *

documentation.short: Did an overflow interrupt occur?
documentation.long: Did an overflow interrupt occur? @return TRUE if overflow triggered, FALSE otherwise

documentation.short: Get the current time.
documentation.long: Get the current time. @return the current time

documentation.short: Turn on the clock.
documentation.long: Turn on the clock. @param scale Prescaler setting of clock -- see Atm128Timer.h

documentation.short: Get prescaler setting.
documentation.long: Get prescaler setting. @return Prescaler setting of clock -- see Atm128Timer.h

documentation.short: Clear the overflow interrupt flag.
documentation.long: Clear the overflow interrupt flag. *

documentation.short: Signalled on timer overflow interrupt.
documentation.long: Signalled on timer overflow interrupt. *

documentation.short: Is overflow interrupt on?
documentation.long: Is overflow interrupt on? @return TRUE if overflow enabled, FALSE otherwise

documentation.short: Set the current time.
documentation.long: Set the current time. @param t the time to set

documentation.short: Enable the overflow interrupt.
documentation.long: Enable the overflow interrupt. *

documentation.short: Turn off overflow interrupts.
documentation.long: Turn off overflow interrupts. *

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface is provided by a Resource arbiter in order to allow users of a shared resource to configure that resource just before being granted access to it.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface is provided by a Resource arbiter in order to allow users of a shared resource to configure that resource just before being granted access to it. It will always be parameterized along side a parameterized Resource interface, with the ids from one mapping directly onto the ids of the other. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Used to unconfigure a resource just before releasing it.
documentation.long: Used to unconfigure a resource just before releasing it. Must always be used in conjuntion with the Resource interface.

documentation.short: Used to configure a resource just before being granted access to it.
documentation.long: Used to configure a resource just before being granted access to it. Must always be used in conjuntion with the Resource interface.

documentation.short: Clients of the higher-level A/D system must implement this interface to specify which channel to sample, and with what parameters.
Obtain reference voltage
Obtain channel.
Obtain prescaler value.
The ReadNow interface is intended for split-phase low-latency reading of small values.
documentation.long:
The ReadNow interface is intended for split-phase low-latency reading of small values. The type of the value is given as a template argument. Because this interface is split-phase, these values may be backed by hardware. Providers of this interface should also provide a Resource interface, and this interface should only be used after the resource has been acquired. Otherwise, the low-latency requirement may be impossible to meet.

This interface has the same calling semantics as the Read interface described in TEP 114, except that it is async. @param val_t the type of the object that will be returned @author Gilman Tolle @version $Revision: 1.5 $ $Date: 2008-06-16 18:58:51 $

documentation.short: Initiates a read of the value.
documentation.long:
Initiates a read of the value.
@return SUCCESS if a readDone() event will eventually come back.

documentation.short: Signals the completion of the read().

Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The Resource interface can be used to gain access to shared resources.
Release a shared resource you previously acquired.
documentation.long:
Release a shared resource you previously acquired. @return SUCCESS The resource has been released
FAIL You tried to release but you are not the owner of the resource @note This command should never be called between putting in a request and waiting for a granted event. Doing so will result in a potential race condition. There are ways to guarantee that no race will occur, but they are clumsy and overly complicated. Since it doesn't logically make since to be calling release before receiving a granted event, we have opted to keep thing simple and warn you about the potential race.

documentation.short: Request immediate access to a shared resource.
documentation.long:
Request immediate access to a shared resource. You must call release() when you are done with it. @return SUCCESS When a request has been accepted.
FAIL The request cannot be fulfilled

documentation.short: Request access to a shared resource.
documentation.long:
Request access to a shared resource. You must call release() when you are done with it. @return SUCCESS When a request has been accepted. The granted() event will be signaled once you have control of the resource.
EBUSY You have already requested this resource and a granted event is pending

documentation.short: You are now in control of the resource.
documentation.long: You are now in control of the resource.

documentation.short: Check if the user of this interface is the current owner of the Resource
documentation.long:
Check if the user of this interface is the current owner of the Resource @return TRUE It is the owner
FALSE It is not the owner

documentation.short: Hardware Abstraction Layer interface of Atmega128 for acquiring data from multiple channels using the ATmega128's free-running mode.
documentation.long:
Hardware Abstraction Layer interface of Atmega128 for acquiring data from multiple channels using the ATmega128's free-running mode.

Because of the possibility that samples may be imprecise after switching channels and/or reference voltages, and because there is a one sample delay on swithcing channels and reference voltages, Atm128ADCMultiple is complex. Two straightforward uses are:

  1. Acquire N samples from channel C:
    1. call getData to start sampling on channel C at the desired rate (note that the choice of prescalers is very limited, so you don't have many choices for sampling rate)
    2. ignore the first dataReady event
    3. use the results of the next N dataReady() events, return FALSE on the last one
  2. Acquire one sample each from channels C1, ..., Cn (this pseudocode assumes that none of these channels are differential)
    1. call getData to start sampling on channel C1
    2. on the ith dataReady event switch to channel Ci+1 by changing *newChannel
    3. the data passed to the ith dataReady event is for channel Ci-1 (the data from the first dataReady event is ignored)
@author Hu Siquan @author David Gay

documentation.short: Initiates free-running ADC conversions, with the ability to switch channels and reference-voltage with a one sample delay.
documentation.long:
Initiates free-running ADC conversions, with the ability to switch channels and reference-voltage with a one sample delay.
@param channel Initial A/D conversion channel. The channel can be changed in the dataReady event, though these changes happen with a one-sample delay (this is a hardware restriction). @param refVoltage Initial A/D reference voltage. See the ATM128_ADC_VREF_xxx constants in Atm128ADC.h. Like the channel, the reference voltage can be changed in the dataReady event with a one-sample delay. @param leftJustify TRUE to place A/D result in high-order bits (i.e., shifted left by 6 bits), low to place it in the low-order bits @param prescaler Prescaler value for the A/D conversion clock. If you specify ATM128_ADC_PRESCALE, a prescaler will be chosen that guarantees full precision. Other prescalers can be used to get faster conversions. See the ATmega128 manual for details. @return TRUE if the conversion will be precise, FALSE if it will be imprecise (due to a change in reference voltage, or switching to a differential input channel)

documentation.short: Returns the next sample in a free-running conversion.
Hardware Abstraction Layer interface of Atmega128 for acquiring a single sample from a channel.
Initiates an ADC conversion on a given channel.
Cancel an outstanding getData operation.
documentation.long: Cancel an outstanding getData operation. Use with care, to avoid problems with races between the dataReady event and cancel. @return TRUE if a conversion was in-progress or an interrupt was pending. dataReady will not be signaled. FALSE if the conversion was already complete. dataReady will be (or has already been) signaled.

documentation.short: Indicates a sample has been recorded by the ADC as the result of a getData() command.
HPL interface to the Atmega128 A/D conversion subsystem.
Disable continuous sampling

documentation.short: Enable ADC interrupt
Is A/D conversion complete? Note that this flag is automatically cleared when an A/D interrupt occurs.
Cancel A/D conversion and any pending A/D interrupt.
documentation.long: Cancel A/D conversion and any pending A/D interrupt. Also disables the ADC interruption (otherwise a sample might start at the next sleep instruction). This command can assume that the A/D converter is enabled. @return TRUE if an A/D conversion was in progress or an A/D interrupt was pending, FALSE otherwise. In single conversion mode, a return of TRUE implies that the dataReady event will not be signaled.

documentation.short: Disable ADC sampling
Clear the ADC interrupt flag
Disable ADC interrupt
Start ADC conversion.
documentation.long: Start ADC conversion. If ADC interrupts are enabled, the dataReady event will be signaled once (in non-continuous mode) or repeatedly (in continuous mode).

documentation.long: Is A/D conversion in progress? @return TRUE if the A/D conversion is in progress, FALSE otherwise

documentation.short: Enable continuous sampling
Read the ADCSRA (ADC control) register

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This is the asynchronous counterpart to the StdContol interface.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This is the asynchronous counterpart to the StdContol interface. It should be used for switching between the on and off power states of the component providing it. This interface differs from the StdControl interface only in the fact that any of its commands can be called from asynchronous context. @author Joe Polastre @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

FAIL otherwise

Stop the component and any pertinent subcomponents (not all subcomponents may be turned off due to wakeup timers, etc.). @return SUCCESS if the component was either already off or was successfully turned off
FAIL otherwise

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The ResourceRequested interface can be used in conjunction with the Resource interface in order to receive events based on other users requests.
This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.request() command.
documentation.long: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.request() command. You may want to consider releasing a resource based on this event

documentation.short: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.immediateRequest() command.
documentation.long: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.immediateRequest() command. You may want to consider releasing a resource based on this event

FAIL You tried to release but you are not the owner of the resource

documentation.short: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.request() command.
documentation.long: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.request() command. You may want to consider releasing a resource based on this event

documentation.long: Event sent to the resource controller giving it control whenever a resource goes idle. That is to say, whenever no one currently owns the resource, and there are no more pending requests

The ArbiterInfo interface allows a component to query the current status of an arbiter.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The ArbiterInfo interface allows a component to query the current status of an arbiter. It must be provided by ALL arbiter implementations, and can be used for a variety of different purposes. Normally it will be used in conjunction with the Resource interface for performing run time checks on access rights to a particular shared resource. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Check whether a resource is currently allocated.
documentation.long:
Check whether a resource is currently allocated. @return TRUE If the resource being arbitrated is currently allocated to any of its users
FALSE Otherwise.

documentation.short: Get the id of the client currently using a resource.
A queue interface for managing client ids when performing resource arbitration.
Enqueue a client id
Check to see if the queue is empty.

documentation.short: Retreive the client id of the next resource in the queue.
Constants for manipulating LEDs.
Turn off LED 0.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 0. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 0; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 0; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn on LED 1.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 1. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 1; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 1; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 2; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 2; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Get the current LED settings as a bitmask.
documentation.long:
Get the current LED settings as a bitmask. Each bit corresponds to whether an LED is on; bit 0 is LED 0, bit 1 is LED 1, etc. You can also use the enums LEDS_LED0, LEDS_LED1. For example, this expression will determine whether LED 2 is on: 
 (call Leds.get() & LEDS_LED2)
This command supports up to 8 LEDs; if a platform has fewer, then those LEDs should always be off (their bit is zero). Also see set(). @return a bitmask describing which LEDs are on and which are off

documentation.short: Turn off LED 1.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 1. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Set the current LED configuration using a bitmask.
documentation.long:
Set the current LED configuration using a bitmask. Each bit corresponds to whether an LED is on; bit 0 is LED 0, bit 1 is LED 1, etc. You can also use the enums LEDS_LED0, LEDS_LED1. For example, this statement will configure the LEDs so LED 0 and LED 2 are on: 
 call Leds.set(LEDS_LED0 | LEDS_LED2);
This statement will turn LED 1 on if it was not already: 
call Leds.set(call Leds.get() | LEDS_LED1);
@param val a bitmask describing the on/off settings of the LEDs

documentation.short: Turn on LED 0.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 0. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn on LED 2.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 2. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn off LED 2.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 2. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface exists to allow a Resource user to cleanup any state information before a shared Resource is shutdown.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface exists to allow a Resource user to cleanup any state information before a shared Resource is shutdown. It should be provided by the user of a shared Resource, and used by the power managment component for that Resource. The cleanup() command will be called by the power manager just before powering down the shared resource. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: This command will be called by the power management component of a shared Resource.
documentation.long: This command will be called by the power management component of a shared Resource. The implementation of this command defines what must be done just before that shared Resource is shut off.
